body:
This for a `Grouper`, not a groupby. 

You prob just want this

```
In [11]: x.pivot_table(columns=['key1','key2'], values='values', index='index')
Out[11]: 
key1     1  2   
key2     a  a  b
index           
1      1.5  3  4
2      1.5  3  4
```

A `Grouper` is useful for doing something time-series like in a pivot.

```
In [24]:        df = DataFrame({                                               
            'Branch' : 'A A A A A A A B'.split(),
            'Buyer': 'Carl Mark Carl Carl Joe Joe Joe Carl'.split(),
            'Quantity': [1, 3, 5, 1, 8, 1, 9, 3],
            'Date' : [datetime.datetime(2013, 1, 1), datetime.datetime(2013, 1, 1),
                      datetime.datetime(2013, 10, 1), datetime.datetime(2013, 10, 2),
                      datetime.datetime(2013, 10, 1), datetime.datetime(2013, 10, 2),
                      datetime.datetime(2013, 12, 2), datetime.datetime(2013, 12, 2),]}).set_index('Date')

In [25]: df
Out[25]: 
           Branch Buyer  Quantity
Date                             
2013-01-01      A  Carl         1
2013-01-01      A  Mark         3
2013-10-01      A  Carl         5
2013-10-02      A  Carl         1
2013-10-01      A   Joe         8
2013-10-02      A   Joe         1
2013-12-02      A   Joe         9
2013-12-02      B  Carl         3

In [26]: pd.pivot_table(df,columns='Buyer',values='Quantity',index=pd.Grouper(freq='M'))
Out[26]: 
Buyer       Carl  Joe  Mark
Date                       
2013-01-31     1  NaN     3
2013-10-31     3  4.5   NaN
2013-12-31     3  9.0   NaN
```
there is an example in the docs [here](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reshaping.html#combining-with-stats-and-groupby)
